channel.title: [317] A Simple Login server, Barebones, Heavily Noted
channel.description:
[size=11pt][b]Information[/b][/size] This is a simple login server I have created. I made it so people who would like to learn how to program RSPS's can learn how everything basically works.
I use DataInput and Output stream, since they support custom data types (all except RSString). This server is for SINGLE THREAD PER CLIENT ONLY! If this is changed, problems may occur with the Input and Output streams.
[size=11pt][b]Download[/b][/size] [url=http://uppit.com/0jevmhdwlauq/Private_Server.rar]Uppit[/url]
[size=11pt][b]Note[/b][/size] Only download if you're serious about private server development! Even If you're a beginner (It's HEAVILY NOTED).
[size=11pt][b]Image...?[/b][/size] Yeah... [IMG]http://i52.tinypic.com/2ih9q9c.png[/img]

item.title: [317] A Simple Login server, Barebones, Heavily Noted
item.dc:creator: @Wintercanon Wintercanon
item.description:
@Wintercanon wrote:

The thread per client approach is not recommended. It’s a better design for when you are serving a single request to a client such as a HTTP server. For a consistent connection I’d advise against it. Sure the DataInputStream and DataOutputStream is useful, but does it have support for the little endian byte order or Runescape’s 2 custom byte orders? Also you will have to implement Runescape’s custom data types: special A, special C and special S.

To others, the IO streams are not blocking, it’s the ServerSocket.accept() method which is blocking. There is a simple workaround for this though.

Lastly instead of using “serverSessionKey = ((long) (java.lang.Math.random() * 99999999D) << 32) + (long) (java.lang.Math.random() * 99999999D);” you could use “serverSessionKey = new SecureRandom().nextLong();”.

Hope my advice helps.

Read full topic
item.source: [317] A Simple Login server, Barebones, Heavily Noted
